node.title: Astronomers Find Scorching Hot Exoplanet Where a Year Lasts 16 Hours
node.description: The extreme exoplanet is so close to its star that it is the fastest planet of its type ever found.

node.title: Who Is Pervis Payne? Tennessee Inmate Freed From Death Row Due to Intellectual Disability
node.description: Pervis Payne's death sentences for the 1987 killing of a woman and her 2-year-old daughter were vacated by a Tennessee judge.

node.title: Nightmarish Sea Beast With Bloody-Looking Mouth Washes Up on San Diego Beach
node.description: The foot-long anglerfish was found by local resident Jay Beiler as he was out walking on Black's Beach.

node.title: More than 80 guests in lockdown at Byron Bay backpackers after confirmed COVID case
node.description: The Member for Ballina says a Byron Bay hostel is going into a lockdown due to a positive COVID case at the venue.

node.title: Jury awards $26 million in Charlottesville "Unite the Right" civil case
node.description: Plaintiffs sought millions in damages from white nationalist and neo-Nazi leaders who organized the two-day rally that left one dead and scores injured.

node.title: Jury resuming deliberations in Ahmaud Arbery murder trial
node.description: The court heard final rebuttal arguments from the prosecution Tuesday morning, after both prosectors and defense delivered closing arguments.

node.title: Eight-year-old boy becomes sixth victim of Waukesha parade crash
node.description: Suspect Darrell Brooks, 39, made his first court appearance Tuesday where his bail was set at $5 million.

node.title: A majority supports keeping Roe v. Wade in place - CBS News poll
node.description: By 2 to 1, Americans say if overturned, it would be a step backward for women.

node.title: In Brussels, a Designer’s Home Awash With His Own Vibrant Creations
node.description: Christoph Hefti makes — and lives with — ebullient carpets and textiles inspired by magical realism and Latin American design.

node.title: German public transportation controllers start checking vaccine papers.
node.description: Passengers will have to show proof of vaccination, recovery from Covid or a negative daily test under a system of random checks.

node.title: Woman Gives Birth on Flight to Atlanta, Cabin Erupts in Applause
node.description: Mom Liliana Acevedo went into labor a month earlier than expected, and happened to be mid-air on a flight from Mexico.

node.title: Multiple Jan 6 Defendants Request Permission To Travel Over Thanksgiving
node.description: Those accused of some of the most serious offenses linked to Capitol attack have requested courts allow them to travel to spend the holiday with family.

node.title: Kangaroos take Horne-Francis with number one selection in AFL draft
node.description: North Melbourne uses the top draft pick to select highly touted South Australian Jason Horne-Francis, with the club hoping the midfielder will play a key role in its rebuild under coach David Noble.

node.title: Turkey Without Covid
node.description: A guide to using rapid tests.

node.title: Former champion says amateur snooker players should not play pro tournaments, after losing to 19-year-old
node.description: After losing in the first-round of one of snooker's biggest tournaments to a 19-year-old amateur, former World Champion Shaun Murphy began criticising the governing body for allowing non-professionals to play big tournaments.

node.title: U.S. to expand vaccine requirements to all land border crossers: AP
node.description: The broader rule, for essential, nonresident travelers, will take effect in January and apply to all non-U.S. nationals, the AP says.

node.title: National Cyber Director Chris Inglis on stemming cyber threats
node.description: Host Michael Morell speaks with the nation's first national cyber director about the prevalence of ransomware and why Russia and China might tolerate criminal hackers on their soil.

node.title: Australia Defamation Case Signals a Crackdown on Ordinary Citizens, Critics Say
node.description: A government minister sued and won over a brief Twitter post that called him a “rape apologist.” A journalist sees “asymmetric warfare.”

node.title: Taiwan Dismisses Kissinger Prediction That China Won't Invade in 10 Years
node.description: An "all-out" attack on Taiwan was unlikely in the next decade, said the former secretary of state, but China would seek to weaken Taiwan's autonomy.

node.title: Is America Creating an Anti-Resilient Society?
node.description: Failure is nature's way of teaching us lessons we can't learn any other way. And protecting our kids—and our citizens—from life's risks isn't possible.

node.title: Real Madrid star found guilty over sex tape blackmail
node.description: French footballer Karim Benzema is found guilty of complicity in the attempted blackmail of a former international teammate over a sex tape.

node.title: Judge John Hodgman on Guests Going Sockless
node.description: Taking your shoes off is polite, but what about going totally foot-naked?

node.title: Making Fresh Cheese at Home Is Worth It. This Recipe Proves It.
node.description: Homemade paneer is tender and delicate and extremely creamy — and the star of this simple tikka.

node.title: Move Over, Diamonds. These Bracelets Are Forever, Too.
node.description: Customers turn to welding machines to mark emotional bonds with physical ones.

node.title: How to Beat the Elements in Norway? Shop.
node.description: Bergen, on the country’s west coast, is among the rainiest cities in Europe, so it’s no surprise that rainwear is a specialty.

node.title: Going to the Source for Spanish Ceramics
node.description: The famed wares of Talavera de la Reina are chic again — centuries after they first emerged.

node.title: In Dapper Croatia, Accessorizing in Style
node.description: Zagreb, the capital, dresses to impress. Its distinctive specialties: neckties, handbags, hats and umbrellas.

node.title: A South African Shopping Site Where Artisans and Community Meet
node.description: At Victoria Yards in Johannesburg, artists, designers and makers of sorbet and spirits draw from their surroundings to create their products.

node.title: Feeling Rich in the Yeezy Gap Jacket
node.description: If you love to talk to people, this is the coat for you.

node.title: Tapping Indigenous Talent in Colombia to Create Modern Fashion
node.description: Cartagena is an enchanting place to shop for high-quality handmade accessories crafted by the country’s many artisan communities.

node.title: Newly Published, From ‘Shaun of the Dead’ to Patricia Highsmith
node.description: A selection of books published this week.

node.title: Poem: Buried Abecedary for Intensive Care
node.description: A poem does its thing when you leave it regretting, just a little bit, learning something you’d swear you already knew.

node.title: Just How Optimized Can Your Life Be?
node.description: An app seeks the outermost limits of productivity.

node.title: They’re Ballerinas — and, Quite Possibly, Murderers
node.description: Rachel Kapelke-Dale’s debut novel, “The Ballerinas,” set in the hothouse world of a Paris ballet academy, follows three dancers hiding a very big secret.

node.title: The Algorithm That Could Take Us Inside Shakespeare’s Mind
node.description: Machine learning programs have recently made huge advances. Stephen Marche tested one against Shakespeare’s collected works, to see if it could help him figure out which of the several versions of Hamlet’s soliloquy was most likely what the playwright intended.

node.title: ‘In the Eye of the Wild,’ a Haunting Memoir About Life After a Bear Attack
node.description: The anthropologist Nastassja Martin has written a slender but expansive book in which she grapples with the physical and philosophical fallout of a near-death experience.

node.title: The ‘Profusely Illustrated’ Life of Edward Sorel
node.description: The legendary illustrator has written a memoir, which tells the story of his Bronx youth through a varied career at the center of the New York media world.

node.title: 8 New Books Coming in December
node.description: A Booker Prize finalist based on a true story, essays from Siri Hustvedt, an imaginative biography of John Milton and more.

node.title: Two actors leave the soap opera ‘General Hospital’ over its vaccine mandate.
node.description: Steve Burton and Ingo Rademacher had refused to comply with a Nov. 1 mandate that applied to actors on the long-running daytime drama’s set.

node.title: What We Learned From Week 11 in the N.F.L.
node.description: The Colts’ Jonathan Taylor has entered the M.V.P. discussion, Kansas City’s defense shocked Dallas, and Cam Newton is not a cure-all for Carolina.

node.title: No. 1 South Carolina Gets a Statement Win Over No. 2 UConn
node.description: The Gamecocks dominated in the second half and gained only the second win in 11 games against Connecticut in the history of the two programs.

node.title: Bucs Rout the Giants, Who Point the Finger at Themselves
node.description: ‘We didn’t do anything really well enough to win the game,’ Coach Joe Judge said after watching his team fall to 3-7. His offensive coordinator, Jason Garrett, was fired.

node.title: How Exercise Affects Your Appetite
node.description: For most of us, exercise impacts our hunger and weight in unexpected and sometimes contradictory ways.

node.title: The Gene-Synthesis Revolution
node.description: Researchers can now design and mass-produce genetic material — a technique that helped build the mRNA vaccines. What could it give us next?

node.title: I Grew Up Poor. How Am I Supposed to Raise My Middle-Class Kids?
node.description: My children do not understand my world and I do not understand theirs.

node.title: How to Find Common Ground With Your Most Problematic Family Members
node.description: To survive a dinner table disagreement with the people you love this Thanksgiving, don’t call it a debate, Dylan Marron argues.

node.title: Who Makes a ‘Good’ Transplant Candidate?
node.description: Evaluation for transplant is an area of medicine where subjective criteria, like whether a person has strong family support, can determine access.

node.title: The Republicans We’re Thankful For
node.description: There are some in the G.O.P. who reject its worst antidemocratic impulses. We should celebrate them.

node.title: End the Trump-Biden Tariffs
node.description: An import tax on chassis is contributing to inflation and port congestion. The government needs to find better ways of increasing manufacturing.

node.title: Wall Street Grudgingly Allows Remote Work as Bankers Dig In
node.description: Finance employees who couldn’t imagine working from home before the pandemic are now reluctant to return to the office. Their bosses can’t figure out how to bring them back.

node.title: Can I Still Travel to Europe? Your Virus Restriction Questions, Answered
node.description: Curfews and lockdowns in some countries have once again made it difficult to plan a visit to the continent. Here’s what we know about the latest restrictions.

node.title: He’s Steering Volkswagen, With His Eyes on Beating Tesla
node.description: Herbert Diess, the chief executive, seeks to cast VW as a dynamic, modern company, but his style risks the ire of its powerful works council.

node.title: A Tech Whistle-Blower Helps Others Speak Out
node.description: Ifeoma Ozoma, who accused Pinterest of discrimination, has become a key figure in helping tech employees disclose, and fight, mistreatment at work.

node.title: How the $4 Trillion Flood of Covid Relief Is Funding the Future
node.description: From broadband to transportation to high-tech medical manufacturing, benefits from America’s pandemic money infusion will linger.

node.title: 30 Million Pounds of Produce in One Day
node.description: The busiest day of the year for the country's largest wholesale produce hub is the Tuesday before Thanksgiving.

node.title: Get Ready for the Baby Yoda Balloon
node.description: A helium-filled Grogu designed by the toy company Funko will fly above the streets of New York in the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade.

node.title: ‘Moulin Rouge!’ Has a New Satine. She’s Amazed She’s Back on Broadway.
node.description: “I didn’t think I’d ever perform on Broadway again,” Natalie Mendoza said.

node.title: In Buffalo, Waiting for the Canadians
node.description: So far, relaxed travel restrictions between the United States and Canada have not led to a big influx of tourists on either side of the New York-Ontario border. Both sides are waiting, not so patiently.

node.title: Meat Is Hard for Hungry Families to Come By. Enter These Deer Hunters.
node.description: Hunters in New Jersey have shared 2.2 million pounds of deer meat since 1997. “This provides a source of protein that we wouldn’t otherwise have,” a food bank manager says.

node.title: The Inflation Miscalculation Complicating Biden’s Agenda
node.description: Administration officials blame the Delta variant for a prolonged stretch of consumer spending on goods, rather than services, pushing up prices and creating a conundrum for the Fed.

node.title: Army Whistle-Blower’s Lonely Death Highlights Toll of Mental Illness
node.description: Ian Fishback revealed abuse of detainees during the Iraq war, but struggled after leaving the service. He died awaiting a bed at the V.A.

node.title: What to Know About Asteroids Dimorphos, Didymos That NASA Will Smash Into
node.description: In a test of Earth's defenses against asteroids, NASA's DART spacecraft will hit the binary asteroid system in 2022.

node.title: China's Warnings Ignored As Taiwan Joins Joe Biden's Summit for Democracy
node.description: A Chinese official called the U.S.'s decision to invite Taiwan "a mistake," while a government newspaper described it as a "dangerous provocation."

node.title: Internal Documents About the Rally Reveal Worries about Porta-Potties—Not Violence
node.description: In this daily series, Newsweek explores the steps that led to the January 6 Capitol Riot.

node.title: Kyle Rittenhouse Fired Lin Wood Over 'Insane' QAnon and Election Fraud Beliefs
node.description: Rittenhouse said his family took issue with the controversial attorney pushing conspiracy theories and "how he thinks he's God."

node.title: WTA stance on Peng makes it human rights champion - former US official
node.description: The Women's Tennis Association has become the world's "most effective" human rights organisation over its leadership on the Peng Shuai case, the former US Ambassador-at-Large for Global Women's Issues…

node.title: America's largest pharmacies fuelled opioid crisis, jury finds
node.description: The retailers have been found guilty of helping create an oversupply of addictive opioid pills in two Ohio counties, in a landmark case.

node.title: LA mall latest to be hit by smash-and-grab thieves
node.description: A group of thieves are pursued by police after smashing windows at a department store, in the latest in a trend of smash-and-grab crimes in California.

node.title: China 'firmly opposed' to US inviting Taiwan to democracy summit
node.description: Taiwan will attend a democracy summit of more than 100 other nations hosted by the United States, angering China.

node.title: 2021 ARIA awards: Sydney-born global star The Kid LAROI takes out best artist, but the night belonged to Genesis Owusu
node.description: And the ARIA Award goes to ... this year's winners include The Kid LAROI, Genesis Owusu, Archie Roach and Budjerah but Amy Shark goes home empty-handed.

node.title: Video Shows NASA's Asteroid-Smashing DART Mission Launch on SpaceX Rocket
node.description: The DART spacecraft, which launched on Wednesday morning, is now hurtling towards an asteroid at 15,000 miles per hour where it is due to arrive in late 2022.

node.title: 'Close the Door Mr. Bear': Watch Video of Bear Shutting Woman's Door on Command
node.description: New Jersey activist Susan Kehoe shared the footage on her YouTube channel.

node.title: Dollar Tree Defends Raising Prices to $1.25 Due to Supply Chain Problems
node.description: The bargain chain store said "freight and supply chain disruptions" meant it would permanently increase prices on most items by the end of Q1 2022.

node.title: US jury awards $25m in damages over Unite the Right rally
node.description: A US jury has awarded millions in damages against the organisers of the deadly far-right rally in Charlottesville, Virginia in August 2017.

node.title: Karim Benzema, French Soccer Star, Is Convicted in Sex Tape Scandal
node.description: The Real Madrid striker was found guilty of being part of an attempt to blackmail a fellow player, charges that had led to his being dropped from his national team for more than five years.

node.title: Homeless Shelter Executives Who Paid Themselves Millions
node.description: One collected annual compensation of more than $1 million. The other used city money for shopping sprees at Neiman Marcus and Manolo Blahnik.

node.title: New Zealand plans to reopen to international visitors by the end of April.
node.description: Emerging from one of the world’s longest lockdowns, the country plans to admit most fully vaccinated travelers by the end of April without a mandatory hotel quarantine.

node.title: Kevin Strickland GoFundMe Raises Over $200K After He Is Exonerated
node.description: Strickland, 62, won't qualify for compensation from the state of Missouri after a judge ruled he was wrongfully conviction for a triple murder in 1979.

node.title: Did Anyone Win the $83 Mega Millions Jackpot on 11/23/2021? Numbers and Results
node.description: There just over a dozen players who each won at least $10,000 in last night's drawing. But did anyone claim the top jackpot prize?

node.title: Marrakesh the goat now the GOAT, fetching Australian record $21,000 price at sale
node.description: A couple from Cobar have rewritten the record books by paying the new top national price for a goat, a 79-kilogram breeding buck who's also "a very nice goat".

node.title: Remote community electrical checks could have saved 11-year-old boy's life, coroner finds
node.description: A young boy who was electrocuted after climbing a verahdah fence in the remote community of Gunbalanya may not have died if cables and connections had been checked and maintained, the NT coroner has found.

node.title: Stars rock ARIAS red carpet on Australian music's biggest night
node.description: The biggest names in Australian music come together in Sydney for the industry's night of nights. Here's how they dressed up for the occasion.

node.title: A woman who fled a remote community in hard lockdown has tested positive. Here's what we know
node.description: Northern Territory authorities say the positive case of greatest concern at the moment is a woman who fled hard lockdown in the remote community of Binjari, hopped into a taxi with three others and entered Katherine. Now, Katherine residents awaiting the fallout.

node.title: Opposition condemns 'mad scramble' in traffic light system legislation
node.description: National's Covid-19 Response spokesperson Chris Bishop said the legislation had been "thrown together hastily" and then dropped with little analysis and no time for public scrutiny. Audio

node.title: Covid-19: Government's border reopening plan stirs mixed emotions
node.description: Many on social media were delighted at the news and shared what it would mean for themselves, their friends and their family.

node.title: Drug checking to be permanent after law passes third reading
node.description: Drug-checking services have been given the all-clear to keep testing the safety of illicit substances at festivals and other locations over summer.

node.title: SpaceX sends NASA craft on collision course with asteroid
node.description: The DART mission is intended to test the feasibility of one day deflecting a threatening asteroid.

node.title: Mark McGowan could intervene if conservationists prevail in Woodside Supreme Court fight
node.description: Mark McGowan says a move to overturn environmental approvals for Woodside's $16.5 billion Scarborough project could put other projects at risk.

node.title: 'To use us as props is disgusting': Aboriginal health worker with COVID-19 slams anti-vaxxers, defends NT response
node.description: Luke Ellis was the first health worker in the NT to contract COVID-19. As he continues to battle the disease, he's taken to social media to dispel misinformation and defended the government's handling of the outbreak in remote communities.

node.title: Stephen Colbert Riffs on Biden’s Order to Release Oil Reserves
node.description: “For those who don’t know, the strategic reserve is a series of caverns filled with fossil fuel and strategically located inside Rudy Giuliani’s head,” Colbert joked.

node.title: NASA Just Launched a Spacecraft That Will Crash Into an Asteroid
node.description: An early morning liftoff kicks off DART, NASA’s first mission to test a spacecraft that could one day save Earth from a deadly space rock.

node.title: World's first planetary defence spacecraft lifts off
node.description: NASA's one-way mission to crash a spacecraft into an asteroid blasts off from California. The mission is to demonstrate the world's first planetary defence system by deflecting an asteroid from a potential doomsday collision with Earth.

node.title: Boy, 7, who drowned in neighbour's pool remembered as 'lovely, affectionate and caring' child
node.description: A boy, 7, who drowned in his neighbour's pool north of Adelaide has been remembered by his grieving family as a "lovely" child.

node.title: KiwiRail group chief executive Greg Miller quits
node.description: KiwiRail group chief executive Greg Miller has resigned effective immediately due to the "recent and sustained allegations in the media" which he denies, the company says. Audio

node.title: Review into use of segregation and force in NZ prisons underway
node.description: The review will look at whether Corrections practices are consistent with the law and policies and procedures. It's one of many sparked by the treatment inmates at Auckland Women's Prison.

node.title: Summer fire risk could be elevated by lower crew levels
node.description: More than 1500 firefighters remain unvaccinated as a government deadline looms on Monday.

node.title: Red StagTimber offers cash incentive for double vaxxed workers
node.description: A Rotorua timber company is dishing out big bucks in a bid to get as many workers possible double dosed.

node.title: Protesters teargassed as they call for Solomon Islands PM to step down
node.description: Police in Solomon Islands use tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse large crowds that turned out in the capital Honiara this afternoon, demanding the country's Prime Minister step down.

node.title: Teens behind 'horrendous' killing of 14 kangaroos weep in court
node.description: The magistrate said the boys, both 17, carried out the act "without any real rationale other than a brain explosion".

node.title: Covid-19 update: 215 community cases in New Zealand today
node.description: There have been 215 new community cases of Covid-19 reported in New Zealand today, including 181 in Auckland, 18 in Waikato, three in Northland and 12 in the Bay of Plenty
